title-group.article-title: William James and Elastic Preaching: Testimony After Exiting the Houses of Authority

ref.mixed-citation: James's description of pragmatism: "The pragmatic method is primarily a method of settling metaphysical disputes that otherwise might be interminable" (1975b, 28).
Lose's greatest concern is that the use of "witness" in a purely legal sense "underplays its more prevalent use" (2003, 146-53).
McClure 2005, 18-26
Charlene Seigfried (1990,373)
"The Idols of Twilight: Pragmatism and Postmodernism" in Stuhr 1997, 87-116.
David Paulsen (1999).
Pete Ward's The Liquid Church (2002).
Hauerwas 2001.
Stuhr's argument that any future of pragmatism must be "more thoroughly pluralistic, more consistently pluralistic than even William James" takes on an added dimension (2003, 179).
Jasper 1993, 139
Knapp and Michaels (1997)

Amy Kittelstrom notes, "James once remarked that 'the whole man within us is at work when we form our philosophical opinions.' So too with all varieties of scholarship and of less codified forms of thought. Thinkers find material in James that leverages more of their 'whole' beings than James could ever have fathomed" (2006).

George Santayana's comments about James: James "kept his mind and heart wide open to all that might seem to polite minds, odd, personal, or visionary in religion and philosophy. He gave a sincerely respectful hearing to sentimentalists, wizards, cranks, quacks and imposters. ... He thought, with his usual modesty, that any of these might have something to teach him-Thus, William James became the friend and helper of those groping, nervous, half-educated, spiritually disinherited, passionately hungry individuals of which America is full" (1998, 55).
Addams and Seigfried 2002, 9-10
Meyer (1995)

his conclusion: "I believe enough evidence has been presented to warrant our seriously considering the claim that the God of William James bears significant resemblance to the God of the Bible. James, of course, was not unaware of this. He made it clear that, in rejecting the God of the philosophers, he was not thereby rejecting the God of the Bible" (1999).
James also speaks about verifiability, which "is as good as verification," for there are a "million" truth processes that "function in the state of nascency" (1975b, 99-100).
Rorty 1989
Stotter 1997, 22
Yarbrough (1999, 164)

Thomas Kuhn writes: "Therefore, at times of revolution, when the normal-scientific tradition changes, the scientist's perception of his environment must be re-educated—in some familiar situations he must learn to see a new gestalt. After he has done so the world of his research will seem, here and there, incommensurable with the one he had inhabited before" (1997, 112).
Davidson 2006
Kent 1991

Donald Davidson famously concluded, "I conclude that there is no such thing as a language, not if a language is anything like what many philosophers and linguists have supposed. There is therefore no such thing to be learned, mastered, or born with. We must give up the idea of a clearly defined shared structure which language-users acquire and then apply to cases. And we should try again to say how convention in any important sense is involved in language; or, as I think, we should give up the attempt to illuminate how we communicate by appeal to conventions" (2005, 107).
Calvin Schrag (2003, 124)
Rorty 1990
Bernstein (1997, 397)
Davidson 2006

Anna Carter Florence puts it well: "You cannot identity a preacher by external things. You can only tell a preacher by her words and whether they create good news for these people, here, today" (2007, 107).
Cormier 2000
Rorty 1999.
Stuhr 1997.
Lucy Rose asserts that expecting "a sermon [to] consistently change people may be expecting too much" (1997, 84)
Shotter 1996, 111
Kent 1999

Davidson also argues, "The most that can be expected is to explain how an interpreter could interpret the utterances of speakers of a single language: it makes no sense to ask for a theory that would yield an explicit interpretation for any utterance in any language" (2006,186).

Stephen Toulmin asserts, "When people ask about the future role of theory and they're talking about theory with a big T, I'm inclined to shake hands with Rorty and say there is probably no legitimate role for theory with a big T; we should be prepared to kiss rationalism good-bye and walk off in the opposite direction with joy in our hearts" (1994, 216).
Knapp and Michaels argue that "no one can reach a position outside practice" and that "theo- rists should stop trying" (1997, 380).
David Hildebrand argues that in taking a theoretical starting point that "frontloads experience with theory and imprisons it within conceptual schemes or language games" (2003,70ff.)

Kevin Porter relates the response of a student after a multiple-choice test: "When the test was handed to me, that nervous, curious feeling turned to frustration and disappointment when I saw a D on the top of my paper.... As we went over the test in class, I did not want to find out which questions I got wrong or listen to the teacher.... I just wanted to quit" (2001, 574).
James writes: "These, then, are my last words to you: Be not afraid of life. Believe that life is worth living, and your belief will help create that fact" (1979b, 56).
